discussion.content: On my exam (5 Aug 2020).
on my exam 3rd September 2020

Two types of ARP attacks exist.

ARP spoofing: A hacker sends fake ARP packets that link an attacker's MAC address with an IP of a computer already on the LAN. 
ARP poisoning: After a successful ARP spoofing, a hacker changes the company's ARP table, so it contains falsified MAC maps. The contagion spreads.
The goal is to link a hacker's MAC with the LAN. The result means any traffic sent to the compromised LAN will head to the attacker instead.

An ARP poisoning attack works by broadcasting unsolicited ARP reply packets. Because ARP is an antiquated protocol with no security, the receiving devices trust this communication and update their MAC:IP address cache table with the spoofed address. A trivial ARP poisoning attack could be launched by adding static entries to the target's ARP cache. A more sophisticated attack can be launched by running software such as Dsniff, Cain and Abel, or Ettercap from a computer attached to the same switch as the target
MAC spoofing attacks change the MAC address. PAGE 305 darril gibson.

A.
ARP poisoning is directed at hosts, not at a switch.

A vulnerability with ARP is that it is very trusting. It will believe any ARP reply packet. Attackers can easily create ARP reply packets with spoofed or bogus MAC addresses, and poison the ARP cache on systems in the network.

Gibson, Darril. CompTIA Security+ Get Certified Get Ahead: SY0-501 Study Guide (p. 306). Kindle Edition.

questions.question_text: An audit found that an organization needs to implement job rotation to be compliant with regulatory requirements. To prevent unauthorized access to systems after an individual changes roles or departments, which of the following should the organization implement?

A company has just completed a vulnerability scan of its servers. A legacy application that monitors the HVAC system in the datacenter presents several challenges, as the application vendor is no longer in business.
Which of the following secure network architecture concepts would BEST protect the other company servers if the legacy server were to be exploited?

discussion.content: There is no need for the legacy server to be connected with the other servers. It's only monitoring the HVAC system. The answer is B. Airgap.

Ideally this systems (ICS and SCADA) are contained within isolated networks, such as within VLAN, that don not have access to the internet. If they are connected to corporate network, they are often protected by a NIPS to block unwanted traffic.
Gibson, SYO-501, page 252

For all those starting their careers please don't ever virtualize legacy or EOL/EOS applications, unless a super higher up tells you to... but then make sure to get in writing and voice your concerns. They are such a pain to support in a virtual environment. We call them crapplications.

An airgap is a metaphor for physical isolation, indicating that there is a gap of air between an isolated system and other systems. When considered literally, and air-gapped system is not connected to any other systems. As an example, many organizations use both classified(red) and unclassified (black) networks. Strict rules ensure that these two systems are not connected to each other. Some rules require that any cables from a red network must be physically separated from black network cables. gibson page 166

I believe the answer is B (Air gap) to better secure the other company servers since the application vendor is no longer in business. Therefore, the vendor is no longer providing any application updates and or performing patch management procedures to better secure the HVAC system. Therefore, for extra protection, I would Air gap the other company servers as a extra layer of security.

If we need to actually get the alerts from the HVAC monitor, I'd isolate with a VLAN. If no one cares about the alerts, air-gap. Unfortunately I've seen both answers be argued as correct in multiple places. The question could use a little more detail.

IRL I'd go with temp sensors and air-gap the damn thing. If the question is just as vague on the test, I guess I'll go with air-gap there too.

I would go with VLAN here. Legacy app is monitoring HVAC, it needs to be on the network. We can isolate it using VLANs though since it doesn’t need to communicate with other servers on the network. Virtualization shouldn’t be an option since this is a legacy application

comments.content: The question indicates a legacy application that is monitoring the HVAC system. Both of them , i mean both the HVAC system and the legacy application, can be on an air gapped network and isolated from the other servers' network.

discussion.content: HVAC are usually part of ICS/SCADA. Air gap them. Best practice.

A. Virtualization. You would need the HVAC monitor on the intranet so that HVAC alerts could be immediately detected. Air Gap would isolate the server completely - no network connection. One of the main assets of virtual servers is that they can be deleted and restored quickly and easily. So if there was an exploitation of the legacy server it wouldn't affect the virtual servers.

white box is a device whose internal structure and processing are known
and understood. This distinction is important in penetration testing, where white-box
testing makes use of knowledge about how an organization is structured, what kinds of
hardware and software it uses, and its security policies, processes, and procedures.
White box tests are useful for simulating the behavior of a privileged insider threat.
